item.title: Distributed Fault-Tolerant Stack
item.description: It’s very exciting to read about all the variety and complexity of today’s software requirements and the abundant opportunity available to innovate across academic disciplines through good software. Programming languages are the bread and butter of the software world. Exploring a bit, I learned a few things about Go programming language and implemented a Distributed Fault-tolerant stack. Most modern large-scale applications are distributed in nature and are designed around high-availability.

item.title: Matter and Spacetime
item.description: If we humans have at-least the perception of the difference between matter and spacetime and even though we are far from being able to explain the workings of it (Gravitons, Super String Theory), wouldn’t it also be worth putting efforts in understanding what allows us those perception in the first place ? And then interpolate to understand higher dimensions ? Here’s a thought of mine that will confuse you (and might make you believe that I don’t know what I’m talking about, but whatever) : Maybe we could develop an initial mathematical model based on the interactions between matter and spacetime as observed and use combination of HPC and Machine Learning to do simulations and inferences for alternatives and uncover other hidden knowledge ?

item.title: High Performance Computing and Machine Learning
item.description: Equations are for eternity. Equations are elegant. Their concise nature that captures the underlying complexity of a system to a degree that satisfies ‘observed realities’ are what scientists and mathematicians consider beautiful. A lot of discovery process for such equations, over the past, took approaches that combined mathematical modeling and computational sciences. Advances in High Performance Computing (HPC) greatly affected this process. In the HPC world, you start with a hypothesis, form a theory over the hypothesis, and additionally run experiments and simulations to build mathematical models that eventually might lead to discovery or newer ideas to explore.

item.title: Quotes
item.description: I often come across inspirational content/quotes on various blog posts, HackerNews, reddit etc that I keep stockpiling into my Evernote. Below are tidbits from this diary of growing wisdom. Hope you like them! Bill Gates The best way to prepare as a programmer is to write programs, and to study great programs that other people have written. In my case, I went to the garbage cans at the Computer Science Center and I fished out listings of their operating system.
